title: Alison Phillips: Tragic lorry deaths are a wake-up call over dark side of society
text:

I had wondered several times how she got here.

It had nagged at my mind – just how did the Vietnamese girl who paints my nails brilliantly for £15 on a Saturday afternoon find herself working in a salon at the bottom of my road.

I could have asked but she barely speaks a word of English. And “how did you get here?” would seem terribly rude.

So I mentally batted it away by telling myself she must have family nearby or got herself a work visa somehow.

There was clearly a very good, legal and happy reason for her arrival in the UK. So I went back to the tricky business of trying to decide between shades of blue.

And then last Friday – five miles from my house – 39 young people were found dead in a refrigerated lorry having endured the most unimaginable ends.

(Image: SWNS.com)

Soon beforehand, Pham Thi Tra My, 26, texted her mum: “My path abroad has not succeeded. Mum, I love you so much. I’m dying because I can’t breath.”

Suddenly it felt the colour on my hands and those of the thousands of British women using Vietnamese nail bars, was a terrible shade of crimson.

The grieving families have already told how women among those who made the deadly journey were doing so in the hope of finding a job in a UK nail bar. Others would have ended up working in restaurants or illegal cannabis farms.

They were hoping for a new life and the chance to send money back to debt-ridden families at home. Duped by criminal traffickers they were sold a dream which ended in nightmare.

This terrible case has been a brutal wake-up call to the danger and criminality that lies just below the surface of our daily lives. How all around us there are people who have risked everything for a part in our booming black economy.

They are the cleaners, workers and gig economy drivers on whom the rest of us have been able to enjoy more comfort at less cost.

Some will say it’s an unavoidable by-product of globalisation as the wealth of some nations exerts an ever stronger ‘pull factor’ to those trapped in poverty elsewhere on our shrinking planet.

But we cannot keep turning a blind eye to the human misery which gets nails painted, cars washed, cheap clothes made and takeaways delivered in the early hours.

It’s time we all start asking.

difficult questions – and there can be nowhere better to start than asking them of ourselves.
